name: 廣義相對論（一）
syllabus:
【授課方式：18週】

**week 1**

overview of SR (Special Relativity) and GR (General Relativity), spacetime geometry, inertial frame and Lorentz transformation, Coordinate and Lorentz invariance, geometrized units

**week 2**

SR revisited, Lorentz contraction, aberration of light, four-vector, special

**week 3**

covariant/contravariant transformation, tensor as a linear mapping machine, partial and covariant derivative, Christoffel symbol, idea of geodesic

**week 4**

acceleration in SR, Rindler horizon, equivalence principle, manifold, local inertial frames, Riemann curvature tensor

**week 5**

curvature tensor and beyond (Ricci tensor, Ricci scalar, Einstein tensor), stress-energy tensor, Einstein's field equation (EFE), review of tensor calaulations and geodesics

**week 6**

from stress-energy tensor to equation of motion, EFE compared with Poission's equation, Schwarzschild metric and weak field limit, stress-energy tensor beyond perfect fluid, time travel to the past

**week 7** 

EFE from LHS to RHS:traversable wormhole and warp drive, energy condition, closed time-like curve, EFE from LHS to RHS:Schwarzschild geometry, time dilation

**week 8** 

review, homework Q&A, Lagragian for the geodesics, Lagragian for the field equation, singularity, 2020 Noble prize in physics, trapped surface, gravitational collapse

**week 9**

_midterm exam_

**week 10** 

correspondence principle, role of post-Newtonian approach, plans for the second half of the course

**week 11: black holes**

Lagragian to geodesic and conserved quanities, black holes, no-hair theorem, Birkhoff's theorem, Kerr-hoposisthes, some paper-and-scissor models for solar system tests of GR

**week 12: black holes** 

regularity of the event horizon, special observers (hovering/infalling/orbiting), Kerr metric and rotating black holes, frame-dragging, Penrose process, Blandford-Znajeck mechanism, black hole astrophysics, area theorem, a few words for linking black hole to other fields (thermal dynamics, quantum gravity) (did not have time to cover: other coordinates and Penrose diagram, tetrad, membrane paradigm)

**week 13: gravitational waves** 

linearized gravity and metric perturbation, gauge condition, GW solution/detection/polarization/power, mass quadrupole

**week 14: gravitational waves**

chirping binary system, gravitational wave spectrum, detector design and sesitivity, multi-messenger astronomy, extreme mass ratio inspiral (EMRI) system, introduction to KAGRA (by our TA) (did not have time to cover: quasi-normal modes, numerical relativity)

**week 15: cosmology** 

Hubble's law, cosmological principle, evolving Universe, Robertson-Walker metric, Friemann equation, equation of state, radiation/matter dominated epoch, density evolution at different epoch, scale factor evolution in different cosmological models

**week 16: cosmology** 

cosmological redshift, thermal history of the Universe, cosmological constant, negative pressure, matter + curvature + Lambda Universes, concordance cosmology model, flatness problem and inflation

**week 17**

_final exam or report_ 

**week 18**

concluding remarks

methodologies.note: ask students to discuss their understandings about the key concepts

prerequisite: ◎Available for junior and senior year B.A. program students (Doctoral program courses excepted) and M.A. program students.
